utterances: John.

Thank you.

You can read all about it at NPR.org/puzzle.
And before we let you go, John, where do you hear us?
What's your public radio station?
That would be WNYC.
WNYC in New York City.
John Roden of New York.
Thanks so much for playing the puzzle this week, John.
Thank you.
OK, Will.
What's up for next week?
Yeah, it's not too hard, I think.
Name certain trees, also name something that trees have, rearrange all the letters to get the brand name of a product you might buy at a grocery or a drug store.
What is it?
So, again, certain trees, also something that trees have, rearrange all the letters to get the brand name of a product you might buy at a grocery or a drug store.
What is it?
You know what to do.
When you've got the answer, go to our website NPR.org/puzzle.
Click on that submit your answer link.
Just one entry per person, please.
Our deadline for those entries is Thursday, April 24 at 3 p.m. Eastern time.
Don't forget to include a phone number where we can reach you at about that time because if you're the winner, we'll give you a call.
And you will get to play on the air with the puzzle editor of the New York Times.
And he is WEEKEND EDITION's puzzle master, Will Shortz.
Thanks so much, Will.
Thanks, Rachel.
I'm Ed Gordon and this is NEWS & NOTES.
It's Thursday and that means we're joined by senior correspondent Juan Williams and our political insiders.
Today they're talking about black leadership after Hurricane Katrina, and a former NFL star who's running for governor of Pennsylvania.
Juan.
Nice hearing from you too.
The competitors will include Martina Navratilova, who has won the singles championship at Wimbledon more than any other woman: a record nine times.
We'd been hearing that she could be retiring later this year and that this could be her last Wimbledon, so we called her in England to see if it was true.
I'm not guaranteeing anything, but that's the plan.
I think playing until I'm 50 is enough.
I think its time to collect my AARP benefits and move on.
I suppose when you say you're not guaranteeing you're retirement, we have to take you seriously, since you did retire once before.
Yeah, well, that was a long time ago.
And you know, at that time I was really ready to hang it up, and I thought if I don't hit another tennis ball the rest of my life I'll be fine.
But when I started playing again, I had so much fun, I thought, you know what, I want to keep doing this.
This could be your last Wimbledon then?
I hope so.
(Laughs)
Do you remember the night before, the morning of, the first match you ever played at Wimbledon?
Oh, sure.
Yeah.
I played, my very first match was on court one against Christine Jane Truman, who had been in the finals in '61.
And, I was 16 years old, and she was 30-something at that time.
So I thought, God, she's really over the hill, you know, I should win this.
(Soundbite of laughter)
No respect for the elders.
And I won the match, and I played in a very tight-fitting dress.
I just remember feeling uncomfortable and wanting to get off the court as soon as possible so I could get out of the dress.
It was the one and only match I played in that dress.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Did you walk out on that court beforehand just to get a feel for it?
To look around?
I had been on that court.
I sort of checked out all the courts when I got there.
I had no idea what court I was going to be on.
I want to know if through all these years you have started matches assuming you would win, the way you assumed you would win that first match at Wimbledon.
Oh, of course.
But the fun part was playing matches that you didn't know if you were going to win, or you knew that you had to play really, really well to win.
And that's what it's about, putting out your best, playing against other number ones.
Because you can't hit a great shot unless the other player forces you to hit a great shot.
Was there a player who forced you to get better over time?
Well, I think it was Chris Evert.
She was the player to beat.
So, I knew if I wanted to be number one, I had to be better than Chris.
What did you do?
Did you train more, did you get stronger?
Yeah, I really wasn't training much at all.
I was just playing.
And I started working out and then I got myself a coach.
Do you feel that you transformed the game, because your physical fitness forced other players then, to become more fit?
Oh, I think so.
I think I definitely turned up the level a couple of notches.
People had to get better if they wanted to catch up to me.
Looking back on your rivalry with Chris Evert.
It's been often pointed out, that even though you were rivals, that you got along.
And it's also been pointed out, that maybe tennis rivals, are not so friendly these days.
Do you think the tone of the game has changed, and the way that players act has changed?
I think most people realize that, hey, you know, you hit the tennis ball, you don't hit the player.
You hit the tennis ball that the other player hits.
And you can be friends off the court and still bring your best game and be extremely, you know, competitive on the court.
Does it help or hurt your game if you dislike the player on the other side of the net?
My favorite match would be playing a person that I trust so much we don't even need linesmen.
We just call the ball as we see it, and know that if in doubt, I call it good for them and she would do the same for me.
What I don't like is these days, the players when they get fired up after a point, they're yelling, come on.
And they're like pumping their fist at the other player.
Like staring them down, like it's, you know, a boxing game or something.
I say, come on, just play ball, just hit the ball and whoever plays better wins, don't do this, you know, macho baloney.
And both the men and the women are doing it and I don't think it's quite kosher.
Martina Navratilova, author of, Shape Yourself.
She is playing at Wimbledon and says it might be her last.
(Soundbite of music)
This is NPR News.
From NPR News, it's ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Andrea Seabrook.

Creating a sculpture of an iconic person can be tricky business, especially when that sculpture is planned for the National Mall in Washington, and when that person is one of the most beloved figures in American history.
The sculpture in question: a massive depiction of the Reverend Martin Luther King, Jr.
A government agency wants it changed.
NPR's Elizabeth Blair reports.
The Martin Luther King Jr. National Memorial is going to be big.
The site for it is a four-acre plot on the Tidal Basin, not far from the Jefferson and Lincoln memorials.
Water, stone and trees are the primary elements in a design inspired by a line in the Dr. King's I Have A Dream speech:
Dr.
MARTIN LUTHER KING, JR. (Late Civil Rights Leader): With this faith, we will be able to hew out of the mountain of despair a stone of hope.
In the original design for the MLK memorial, a bust of Dr. King emerges almost organically out of the side of the Stone of Hope.
To get to the stone, you would walk through two rocks symbolizing the Mountain of Despair.
That design won the competition set up by the U.S.
Fine Arts Commission, the federal agency that approves anything that gets built on the National Mall, headed up by Thomas Luebke.
Thanks, Ed.
We're joined now by Tara Wall.
Tara is a Republican strategist and senior adviser to the Republican National Committee.
She joins us from KUHF in Houston, Texas.
Also with us, Professor Ron Walters.
Ron Walters is a professor of political science at the University of Maryland.
He's been an adviser to Jesse Jackson's presidential campaigns.
He's here with me in our Washington, DC, NPR studios.
